profileText: A Delegate from Maryland; born in Annapolis, Anne Arundel County, Md., in 1723; received a liberal schooling; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice; member of the committee of safety in 1774 and 1775; member of the Maryland provincial conventions in 1774, 1775, and 1776; one of the trustees of the Lower Marlboro Academy in 1775; second major of battalion, Prince Georges County; Member of the Continental Congress in 1775 and 1776; judge of the court of admiralty in 1776; member of the executive council on the organization of the state government in February 1777; chancellor of Maryland from March 10, 1778, until his death in Upper Marlboro, Prince Georges County, Md., September 23, 1789.

researchRecord.name: 1780, 1 piece.
researchRecord.description: A photocopy of a letter with a transcript from John Rogers to George Rogers Clark written on July 22, 1780. In the letter, John Rogers writes with news of the Spanish occupation of Mobile and siege of Pensacola. The original letter is owned by the St. Louis Historical Society.
